comment: Prof Sachs is retiring this year and thank god for it. He was extremely rude and stubborn and was very inaccessible outside of class. He is not very tech savvy and messed up multiple exams/assignments in D2L and refused to fix them. He made it very clear he did not care. He "accidentally" locked our entire course right before finals! Good riddance!

Took this class for study abroad over the summer and immediately regretted it. In the lectures he is constantly repeating himself. The lectures are pretty much pointless in the grand scheme of the class. Did not grade papers on content, only nitpicked your writing style. Had to do a pencil drawing. He knew we were not artists and graded unfairly.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The class was not too difficult or demanding beyond what I expected from a May-mester, but the professor is too old-fashioned. Showed no respect, sympathy, or care when I felt sick/dizzy from the required heavy metals used for the paintings. Don't take this class if you care for not getting potential lead/cobalt poisoning!

He is a good professor and very knowledgeable about art history, but he's also very old fashioned. His class is entirely lecture based with no online notes, so if you don't come to class you have no way of knowing necessary information. He's also a strictly auditory professor, all the notes come from him talking.

He has some really dated political opinions so be cognizant of that when choosing to take him for this class. Also, if you have ADHD or any other attention span issues this isn't the class for you, he has an entirely auditory teaching style and doesn't do much to accommodate those who learn differently.

Highly recommend, tests were all identifying the artist to the art (use google images), quizzes are based off of just paying attention in class, and no webcam for both. attendance isnt graded, hes passionate about what he talks about and understands us being interested on listening is more important.

Very nice guy, knows ALOT. Like if you care about art at all he's such a great lecturer to have. Made me care a bunch about the art I was learning about so it made the class enjoyable. He is particular though, so know what he's looking for in assignments but he's always willing to tell you. Ask questions, pay attention, and the assignments are easy

He was teaching in Paris most of my Semester so our class received very little attention. I've enjoyed all my art history classes so far and received an A in all of them until this one. He dead named students, was slow to answer emails, messed up a study guide causing students to do poorly on a test and didn't care. I would avoid this professor.

One of the worst classes I've ever taken, horribly unorganized, doesn't respond to emails for 2 weeks, ignores student's concerns, confusing grading on discussions, poorly designed quizzes and tests, I'm sure he would be alright in person but for the love of God do not take him online. He doesn't set anything up correctly & is confusing.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Something he told us at the beginning of the course was to never stress about his class. This is true! He will constantly give us extra time before the test if we aren't ready for it. His lecture are very audio only (not much visual notes) so you must be in class to get the information. If you pay attention you will get at least a B.

Sign-in sheet every class; four exams, but there's a 8-10 page paper due at the end of the semester on one work of art; Tests are 20 question image identifications (year, medium, artist, title), about 20 difficult multiple choice questions, and an essay. He wants you to fail and thinks he's the smartest and best. PPT on D2L, only images, no notes.

He is so full of himself that he put himself in the lectures and on an exam. He passes around a sign-in sheet every class. There are only four exams, but there are also about four 1-2 page papers. His tests are 40 question image identifications. He shows the slides, and give you multiple choice answers on which artist produced it.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: was really excited to take him, since Id only heard positive things about him, but hes been a complete disappointment. he definitely knows his stuff which is great and all, but he bashes other peoples political AND religious beliefs to get point across. He has a big ego. Sometimes he cancels class w/o telling us ahead. hes an impossible grader
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Sachs is a great guy, hilarious, entertaining. I actually remember the things he tells me because he makes the class so fun, but he grades pretty hard on the paper. Victorian ARH was set up as a seminar class, so you only have participation, one 8 page paper, and a presentation as your grade. Beware if you don't write or speak well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Professor Sachs is incredibly knowledgeable and a pretty nice, fair guy. However, if you have ADHD (like forreal) don't take him. Just don't. His lectures can be very dull. I have ADHD and I prefer classes where I can write notes from the projector but he just puts up images and talks the whole time which is just not for me. He also rambles a bit

This professor is not approachable and makes his tests insanely difficult. You have to study for hours because each test was 8 chapters in the book. Its way too much material covered in a VERY POOR teaching style. Not an easy A and not worth taking. Dont let this professor drop your GPA!!!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: This was a ridiculously hard class for a Gen. Ed. Art class. DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR! The tests were almost impossible and no one made A's on them. The tests were unfair even if you study for hours...
rating_tags: Tough Grader--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He made Art History enjoyable which is a pretty difficult thing for professors to do, from my experience at least. Tests are easy and multiple choice. No book. He really stresses good writing skills on the papers, but he's really not that tough of a grader. Interesting and fun lectures. I would definitely take another class from him

2.5 He's a good teacher, engaging, entertaining, but his tests are too difficult (compared to every other class I've taken at KSU). Showing up to class, paying attention, taking notes, and briefly reviewing for a test is a C (unless you have an impeccable memory). Its a shame because I do like his teaching style, but I despise and dread his tests.

Funny respected guy. very nice. lectures were interesting and he made funny noises. didnt pay attention in class so the tests were passable but still had to put effort in to get an A. Had three group paper things as a group, pretty easy.

Professor Sachs is a nice man and very knowledgable about the class content. However, his tests can be kind of tough and confusing. I studied hard for every test and made two C's, one being the final. He does offer 5 points extra credit added to your overall grade at the end of the semester and accepts late work so it levels out.

Overall, you will have to work for the grade you want for sure. Tests are challenging but he gives a study guide. If you do it you'll be fine on the tests. He does 3 group papers over the semester which are annoying because one person ends up writing the whole thing usually.

Professor Sachs is a phenomenal teacher. Art history can be an passionless and enigmatic subject without the proper insight and instruction. Professor Sachs doesn't offer his opinion on subject matter, he offers legitimate substance backed by years of intellectual rigor. I highly recommend taking any and every class of his.

SERIOUSLY SO HARD!! I am an Art Ed major and this was the first Art History class I have taken. I was blown away by the amount of content he wanted us to know. He shows 5 pieces of art that we have never discussed and you have to make an educated guess on who it is on the test. Tests are hard. Got a 46 on the first and a 78 on the second..
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: This professor clearly had a passion for what he was teaching. He was very knowledgable about art of all kinds. However, his exams were insanely difficult which came as a surprise to me.

I'm an Art History major so there was no way to get around not having Dr. Sachs. He really knows his stuff and his lectures are super funny and interesting. You have to STUDY for his tests. Everyone says they failed the first test but I made an 83, and had an A in the class. Study the works and listen/take good notes and you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Sachs is a fantastic teacher. Basically, if you show up and listen, you will pass with no issue. He teaches the lecture as if he is having a conversation with you, keeping you intrigued. Dr. Sachs also provides a Study Guide before each exam that gives everything you will need to know for the exam. Extra Credit is Provided!

Everyone failed the first test. Including me, and I'm a straight-A student, it's not like I was slacking off. He made it out like this was normal! Dude, if EVERYONE fails the test, it's not the students' fault. He's a super funny guy, so I was loving the class until the tests started rolling around. Now I'm very disappointed, and stressed out.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Dr. Sachs is a charismatic lecturer who's passionate about art and eager to see students get it. He'll explain on day 1 that showing up, keeping up and participating are vital. This all was true. Tests and writing assignments are challenging but fair, and measure several different skills. And you get to see some great art work. Loved this class!

Ok I enjoyed his class overall but his time management skills are non existent. He will go incredibly slow with stories/tangents towards the beginning of a unit (1-2 artists per class). The day before the test, he realizes he is nowhere near finished and rushes through 20-30 artists in one class, so fast to the point that it's impossible keep up.

He tends to ramble on during lectures which caused each of our tests to be moved back at least a week. His "study guides" are not helpful at all. I study 7-10 hours for each test and only get 70's when I used to get A's on my previous art history tests. Wouldn't recommend him, but he's a very nice guy with an interesting class.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Dr. Sachs is the best professor in the Art History Department! His lectures are interesting. The tests are easier than most art history classes I've taken! I've really enjoyed his class!

Good professor, knows his stuff, funny and a nice guy. came into this class thinking it 's art so it will be easy. Wrong. You NEED to study for his tests, if you don't you will fail. The group assignments are annoying cause not everyone will help. Don't really use the book. There are not a lot of assignments so doing well on the tests is imparative

Phenomenal professor, I have taken him every semester. He is incredibly knowledgable and always has a story to share. He thrives at evoking good conversation and making you think- he keeps your attention and makes the topic interesting. Attend class, listen, focus on the big picture, don't kill yourself studying, write on what interests you.

Go off the powerpoints and lectures for the test and you'll be set for this class. Definitely go to class and participate in the lecture, and don't forget to ask questions!! Most importantly, make sure you get good people for your group essays. If you hate doing all the work in group projects, don't take this class cause there's one for each unit

Sachs always made class enjoyable, lectures were interesting and he always had good stories regarding the works of art shown in class. Exams weren't hard 30 MC and pretty much straight from the notes, powerpoint, and study guide. Class isn't hard as long as you show up, pay attention, and take notes.

Really enjoyed this class. He makes lectures interesting always putting interesting facts in about artists. He posts study guides and lets you know what kind of questions will be on the tests. Not an impossible amount of work to do, but you will definitely need the book and do some studying. I struggle with specifics in history but this is do-able.
This professor is great. Easy material, hes friendly, and interactive. Tests, to me, seem harder than expected, but still a nice easy-A.

Here's all you need to know: There are 3 group assignments, unfortunately. 4 tests that cover 1 or 2 chapters; DETAILS ARE EVERYTHING IN THIS CLASS. TAKE NOTES. The littlest things are on the tests. He's an amazing speaker and loves what he does. Power points are online but get the book and listen to him 100% of the time. Trust me. Takes attendance

Dr Sachs is the best professor I have ever had in college.  If you love Art History you will love his class.  He is a master story teller.  He class is tough though.  I made an A so I would think anyone can.  Only one poem due - no papers.  3 tests total.  Awesome teacher and artist himself.
An Excellent speaker. Keeps the lecture entertaining and interesting. Test are a little hard but if your good at memorizing it should be an easy A.

He gives you 4 tests including the final, each test is about 4-5 chapters and you must know EVERY single little detail in each chapter or else you will fail. No matter how much I studied the book and his PowerPoints I would still fail his tests because he tests you on the things that don't matter. DO NOT TAKE! Unless you are a historyArt genius.

Very hard! I have not heard one grade above a 70. He has many study guides for each test. wants you to know over 50 images for test along with date , title, medium and artist. only 20 or so are on test. there are 20 historical fact questions and they are off the wall questions. you will be given unknown 5 images & you must name the artist & period

Prof Sachs is a nice guy who is obsessed with his subject. Sadly, the lectures are generally boring and its easy to lose focus. Tests are very hard, and study guides don't help you much. Gives a lot of extra credit opps, though. He seems to be very unorganized. He refused to put in two of my grades. Why? Don't know. Wouldn't answer my emails.

Not the easiest class but it ws okay. He is a super funny guy and really passionate about what he teaches. It's just not the most interesting subject. there were 3 tests and 3 in class group writing assignments. the written work is easy but the tests are pretty hard. make sure to take notes and study study study. the book is helpful.

Focuses more on the lives of artists instead of their work and sticks on an artist for 30 mins. It's easy to zone out. Generally cool, but he moved tests up 2 weeks w/o sending an email and attendance isn't mandatory so watch for that. If you don't wanna speak up, participation is 10 points off your average so you might what to find something else.

Knowledgeable. However he rambles and gets off subject. His class is very boring and Im an art major. He is extremely unorganized. He moves test dates ahead of time which is not fair for any student who is trying to balance other classes and work. I would not recommend.

I think this was an extremely boring class, the material is painful. But he gives you three extra credit opportunities, three easy written assignments, and three easy multiple choice question exams. If you can stay awake in class, you will do well in the class.

He is a nice person and helpful if you go to him for help. His tests are hard though. He doesn't go over what will be on the test at all and is kind of all over the place. Its a hard class for it to be a gen ed, it could drop your gpa.

Very nice man, but often does not make sense. He goes into a lot of detail on things that are irrelevant. the tests are hard because he doesn't go over what it is about. He is not very clear, and he thinks in a very different way than the majority of people, but the class isn't that bad. he is eccentric and has good art. not the best, not worst

I took Dr. Sachs for 19th century art, and the class was definitely not easy. There were 3 tests, and 3 quizzes, and an 8 page paper.You really have to read between the lines when taking notes, because it's hard to tell the difference between anecdotes and the things he wants you to know.He also cancelled class alot.He was a good teacher, but tough

Make sure to do study guide and look at powerpoints. Attendance is a big part of ur grade. He is a pretty good teacher and funny but tests are hard. Will have to go to some events outside of class and do reports over it. Overall good class and professor.

GREAT professor very knowledgeable.  Learned so much about ART HISTORY.  He was very interesting.  Would take again if I had the opportunity.  Very kind and compassionate.  ALWAYS answers student emails which is very important to me.

I love this man.  He is funny, and really great.  The tests are hard, but you just have to study.  He knows his material and will do what he can to help you.  I recommend taking his class if you do.  I enjoy his lectures!

Sachs was very interesting. He tells stories that go with the artist and will go into detail about the art. He has 4 test which are challenging if you do not know the material. He always says he will test us on what we know and not what we do not know. He gives capsule study guides with the artist and time period. I recommend you take him.
This man is amazing. He really does are about his students, and he'll help you if you put in the effort. Make sure you pay attention in class, and the tests are fairly easy. Awesome teacher.

this class is very easy. he posts the study guides online along with powerpoints, so as long as you study those you're fine. there are also some required events and group papers that mostly everyone does on vista. sometimes I feel like he makes up half of the things he says, and I found his classes pretty boring despite my interest in art.

sachs is awesome if you like art history... hes absolutley insane, though. he makes the craziest noises during class but i honestly think he does that to keep people awake. tests are really intense but if you pay attention, find interest in the subject, and study you will make an A or B.

Ive had him for several classes and Sachs is the man. He knows a ton about art history and is a very friendly and funny teacher. he has seen most of the art in person so has good stories to tell. He is also an artist himself which is great. if you can memorize the images youll get an A or B at the very least. Ill be taking my 4th class w him in fal

text is very helpful. you dont HAVE to go to class- but if you DONT, you miss out on a LOT of important info for tests. tests arent EASY but arent HARD. very interesting class and a funny guy! i had to read my book and study (he gives studyguides). but i made an A and learned a lot! he knows ALOT of history in general-but art is very interesting!

So smart - has a ton of random knowledge, but sometimes this meant we wouldn't finish the notes in time or class would be held late / he would give a class worth of notes in like 10 minutes. If you read and take lots of notes and study the crap out of them, you will be fine. Don't expect him to pick the most obvious artists for the Unknowns.

I thought this class was very hard! He's a great guy-very entertaining but the tests were really pretty hard! Attendance is a must bc its graded. The better he knows you the higher the grade. Its a miracle I got a B bc I thought I was a C for sure. Tests are hard bc he gives multiple possible answers! Good luck!

Easy class, he gets a little boring when he rambles.  Not necessary to take notes, just learn images and look over book and study guides before tests.  He offers extra credit, and make sure that you go to all of the exhibits that you're supposed too.

I have taken him for several classes. Very good professor, great sense of humor (tells jokes all the time), very easy to get along. Although he is awesome, his tests are hard. Take good notes and study the images!!!! He does not do extra credit often. Books are recommended but not necessary. He knows his stuff and makes it interesting. Take him!!!!

Sachs knew a lot of interesting tidbits about art. Make sure you study the pics in the books b/c that is what most of the test questions are on. I did pretty bad on all tests except one but pulled an A. Attendance is graded. There is a huge group project--big part of grade. Other graded assignments to help pull up grade. Very fair.

I LOVED THIS MAN!!! His class was lots of fun. He taught things with a lot of passion and made it interesting. He did take attendance for extra credit. The only thing is you have to buy about 5 tickets and see 6 art events but I think everyone does that. I was sad when this class ended he is awesome!
AVOID THIS CLASS! TEST ARE EXTREMELY HARD AND U DONT KNOW WHAT IS GONNA BE ON IT !

Class is interesting if you are into art history. He does a lot of lecturing every class and it is very boring. Take notes and etc, information will be on the test. When you do take the test hint hint the pictures come straight from the readings, the multi choice is tricky use the study guide that he gives you in you will be okay in the class.

Sachs is brilliant in his subject, kinda sarcastic, expects much, tests are tough, but study what he tells you and you will do fine, go to class, it will benefit you and he is pretty funny. I took him for art history II and it was an enjoyable class!

Even if his tests were very hard, you had plenty of opportunities to make up your grade! Makes students become involved in school by attending art galleries and plays. I highly suggest taking this teacher. I thought it was going to be a nightmare b/c I had to take this class an a gen elective, but I loved it!!! His PPT's are the key!!! Loved Him
Very smart and intresting but he did not care about the class or teaching it. The test are very hard and you never know whats going to be on them, i rec. not taking him.
This is not as easy as we would think..It gave me a hard time and headaches trying to go to these events...If you take it know that it is not going to bea an easy A.

Even though this is a gen ed class, its hard. But its not the professor, everyone thinks this class is hard. Don't go in thinking its going to be a piece of cake, but don't worry either. Sachs will help you, he really knows what he's talking about.

Sachs is fun. Lectures can sometimes be boring, but he is wacky so that helps. His tests are relatively hard-so STUDY! Does take off points for attendance. I NEVER opened my textbook (waste of $80) and still pulled off an A. JUST TAKE NOTES AND STUDY!
Very interesting, and great artist.  He has a great sense of humor.
Sachs was funny. Really knows his stuff! Tests were extremely hard and as noted before "I'm a straight-A, Dean's list student and worked hard for a B-"

I loved Dr. Sachs, he does great lectures and is really funny, tells you things you would have never known about art, great discussion class, really makes you think. Only complaint is that the test were somewhat hard. Like another person on her said: work really hard to get a "B" when the rest of my classes I got "As".

Excellent professor!  Very helpful and interesting lectures in what could be a somewhat boring subject at times. Take lots of notes and study a little every night and you will get an A in the class.  Waiting till the last minute to study you may not do so well.

He has the best lectures!  If you like Art Hitory then you'll really enjoy his class. He likes opinioned people to speak out during class which make group discussion a lot of fun.  His tests are a little difficult but as long as you pay attention and go to class, it should be fairly simple.  And he's kinda cute in his own way.  I  really like him!

Best choice for Survey I and II.  He may go off on the occasional tangent but its all in fun.  He is specific on what will and will not be on tests.  Listen to the lectures and know the images given and your good to go.  Recommended!
I did not care for this class set up. The tests seemed very hard to me no matter what I studied. I worked pretty hard to get a B and it was my only B that semester, the rest were A's.
No Comments
GREAT teacher. He is very clear about what will be on tests. very willing to give extra help. makes what could be really booring engaging and fun.

For a boring class he does what he can. Attendence is a big deal and he takes it every class by passing around a sheet. Don't try to be slick and have your buddy sign you in though... he compares the handwriting or something (believe me I tried it). Very n

Very nice man.  This is not a fun class but he does his best to keep his student's attention and make it as interesting as possible.  He is very willing to help if you ask.  He never took attendance  in my class. If you never go but read the chapter and learn the images you should be ok on tests.

Disorganized, did not even make his own slides for instruction so often he was making the lesson up as he went. Attendance is worth 20% of final grade but he didn't mention that until the last week of class. Repeats some things way too much, did not even mention other items that were on the final.
Had him for art appreciation. Very easy and laid back class. He talks a lot, but it's usually interesting and funny stuff.

Art survey 3 is really hard. For each of the exams it was more than 150 pictures to remember plus dates, places, and names and it's all fill in the black. His lectures do ramble on and I avoid his class.
The stuff he teaches is pretty boring, but he's got a good sense of humor, so it's not too bad...you take lots of notes, but his tests are fairly easy.
